name: Microscopy and Digital Imaging
introduction: Students can learn how to use microscopes and digital imaging software to capture and analyze images of cells, tissues, and organisms. They can explore different types of microscopes, including light, electron, and confocal microscopes, and learn how to prepare samples for imaging.

name: Microscopy and Data Visualization
introduction: Students can use microscopy and data visualization tools to create interactive visualizations of microscopy data. This can include creating heatmaps, scatterplots, and other types of visualizations to help students explore and understand their data.

name: Microscopy and 3D Printing
introduction: Students can use microscopy and 3D printing technology to create three-dimensional models of cells, tissues, and organisms. They can learn how to use microscopy data to create accurate models, and then use 3D printing to produce physical replicas of their models.

name: Microscopy and Artificial Intelligence
introduction: Students can learn how to use artificial intelligence algorithms to analyze microscopy data. This can include using machine learning algorithms to identify patterns and features in the data, as well as using deep learning algorithms to classify images and predict outcomes.

name: Microscopy and Virtual Reality
introduction: Students can use virtual reality technology to explore microscopy data in a three-dimensional virtual environment. They can learn how to use virtual reality software to interact with microscopy data, and explore different visualization techniques to help them better understand their data.

name: Microscopy and Mobile Apps
introduction: Students can create mobile apps that use microscopy data to provide real-time information and insights. This can include apps that help diagnose diseases, monitor environmental conditions, or track the health of cells and tissues.

name: Microscopy and Citizen Science
introduction: Students can participate in citizen science projects that use microscopy data to study the environment and biodiversity. They can learn how to use microscopy tools to collect data and contribute to scientific research, while also developing their scientific literacy and critical thinking skills.

name: Building a Microgreens Monitoring System
introduction: Students can build a system that monitors the growth of microgreens using sensors and a microcontroller board like Arduino or Raspberry Pi. They can set up the system to collect data on temperature, humidity, and light levels and analyze the data to optimize the growth of microgreens.

name: Designing an Automated Microgreens Watering System
introduction: Students can design and build a watering system for microgreens that automatically waters the plants based on soil moisture levels. They can use a microcontroller board like Arduino or Raspberry Pi to control the watering system and sensors to measure soil moisture levels.

name: Developing a Microgreens Recipe Website
introduction: Students can create a website that provides recipes for microgreens. They can research different microgreens varieties and come up with recipes that incorporate these plants into meals. They can use website builders like Wix or WordPress to design and develop the website.

name: Creating a Microgreens Mobile App
introduction: Students can design and develop a mobile app that provides information on growing microgreens. They can include features like a plant identification tool, a database of growing tips, and a forum for sharing experiences. They can use app development tools like Appy Pie or Thunkable to create the app.

name: Designing a Microgreens Virtual Reality Experience
introduction: Students can create a virtual reality experience that allows users to explore a microgreens farm. They can use software like Unity or Unreal Engine to design the experience and 3D modeling tools like Blender or Maya to create the microgreens farm environment.

name: Building a Microgreens IoT Sensor Network
introduction: Students can build an Internet of Things (IoT) sensor network that monitors the growth of microgreens in real-time. They can use sensors to collect data on temperature, humidity, and light levels and transmit the data to a central server. They can use IoT platforms like AWS IoT or Azure IoT to set up the sensor network.

name: Creating a Microgreens Educational Video Series
introduction: Students can create a series of educational videos on growing microgreens. They can research different microgreens varieties and come up with tips and tricks for growing these plants. They can use video editing software like Adobe Premiere or iMovie to create the videos.

name: Setting up a microgreens garden
introduction: Students can start by setting up a mini indoor garden and growing different types of microgreens. They can learn about the different types of seeds, soil, and lighting conditions required for growing healthy microgreens.

name: Using technology to monitor growth
introduction: Students can use sensors and other monitoring devices to keep track of the growth of their microgreens. They can learn how to collect and analyze data to optimize the growing conditions for their plants.

name: Developing a microgreens recipe book
introduction: Students can experiment with different ways to incorporate microgreens into their meals and create a recipe book. They can use information technology to document and share their recipes with others.

name: Building a hydroponic system
introduction: Students can learn about hydroponics and build a system to grow microgreens using water and nutrients instead of soil. They can use technology to monitor the pH levels and nutrient levels in the water to ensure the best growing conditions for their plants.

name: Designing a microgreens app
introduction: Students can learn about app development and design an app that helps people grow and care for their own microgreens. They can use information technology to research and compile information about different types of microgreens, growing conditions, and troubleshooting tips.

name: Conducting experiments with microgreens
introduction: Students can design and conduct experiments to investigate different factors that affect the growth of microgreens, such as light, temperature, and moisture levels. They can use technology to collect data and analyze the results of their experiments.

name: Creating microgreens art
introduction: Students can use their microgreens as inspiration to create artwork, such as paintings, drawings, or sculptures. They can use technology to document their creative process and share their artwork with others.

name: Organizing a microgreens market
introduction: Students can organize a market to sell their microgreens and share their knowledge with others. They can use technology to promote their market and advertise their products to potential customers.

name: LED Brightness Control with Resistors
introduction: In this activity, she will delve deeper into the world of electronics by creating a circuit that includes an LED and a resistor. Resistors are essential components in circuits as they control the flow of electrical current. By adding a resistor to the LED circuit, she will learn how resistance affects the brightness of the LED.
goals: Understand the basic components of a simple circuit (LED, resistor, battery).
Learn about the concept of electrical resistance and its role in controlling current flow.
Observe the relationship between resistance and the brightness of an LED.
materials: Resistors (various values, around 220 ohms is a good starting point)
instructions: Gather the necessary materials: LED, resistor (around 220 ohms), coin cell battery, and wires.
Connect one leg of the LED to the positive (+) terminal of the battery using a wire.
Connect the other leg of the LED to one end of the resistor using another wire.
Connect the other end of the resistor to the negative (-) terminal of the battery using a wire. The LED should light up.
If the LED doesn't light up, check the connections and ensure the LED is connected with the correct polarity (longer leg to positive).
Experiment with different resistor values to observe how it affects the brightness of the LED.
tips: Try experimenting with different resistor values to observe how it affects the LED's brightness.
Emphasize the importance of correct polarity when connecting the LED.
observations: Can she explain the role of the resistor in the circuit?
Can she demonstrate how to connect the LED with the correct polarity?
Can she predict how changing the resistor value would affect the brightness of the LED?
extensions: Introduce the concept of Ohm's Law and explore the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance.
Experiment with circuits using multiple LEDs or LEDs of different colors.
Build more complex circuits with switches, sensors, or integrated circuits.
resources: Online tutorials or videos demonstrating basic circuits with LEDs and resistors.

name: Atmospheric Water Generator- Peltier Cooling Method
introduction:
At first pure air is passed through small fans on to a cooling or condensating object (Peltier heat sink plate on cooling side),this makes a small condensatate layer of water on the plate surface.
The time passes-  the air is continuously flown on to cooling plate makes the condensate water to precipitate and from water droplets.Thes droplets are made to fall into the collection pit and purified.
The whole process is carried out in aseprating chamber where water and air are separated by exhaust fans.
instructions:
Standard operating procedure:
step 1: place the apparatus AWG or water producing instrument near the open window or out door.
step2: After placing AWG at a perfect location, connect it to an adapter or SMPS power supply unit(never put outside/do not expose it to water)
NOTE: HOUSE HOLD POWER REQUIREMENT-
input power- 220v -connected to main switch board
out put power- 12v-20 amp- connected to AWG, PROVIVDED WITH SUITABLE PORT/DC JACK.
B. SOLAR POWER REQUIREMENT- 12 v-200w-SOLAR PANEL,NO SMPS required.
step3: check out proper connections and switch on the main supply(220v), observe fans are moving and producing heat on top
note: never touch the SPMP power supply/adapter while it is ON and don't spill any water on it.

name: Step watering system
introduction: I need to control the flow of water in my fields
goals: To reduce the manual work of farmers
instructions: Purchase a timer: You will need a timer that can be programmed to turn on and off at specific times. There are many affordable timers available on the market, and you should be able to find one that suits your needs and budget.

Install valves: You will need to install valves at the beginning and end of each section of your field. These valves will allow you to control the flow of water to each section. You can purchase simple manual valves or automated valves, depending on your budget.

Connect the timer to the motor: Connect the timer to your motor, so that it turns on and off at the programmed times. You can do this by wiring the timer to the motor, or by using a plug-in timer that you can simply plug into the motor.

Connect the valves to the timer: Connect each valve to the timer, so that they open and close at the appropriate times. You can do this by wiring the valves to the timer, or by using a plug-in timer for each valve.

Set the timer: Set the timer to turn on the motor at the desired times, and to open and close the valves for each section of your field. Make sure to test the system to ensure that it is working properly.
